pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:2.1: The nuns’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:3.1: The chapter on offenses entailing acknowledgment
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:4.1: 2-8. The training rules on asking for oil/honey/sugar/fish/meat/milk/curds
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:5.3: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:5.4: At that time the nuns from the group of six ate oil after asking for it .
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:5.5: … ate honey after asking for it.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:5.6: … ate sugar after asking for it.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:5.7: … ate fish after asking for it.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:5.8: … ate meat after asking for it.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:5.9: … drank milk after asking for it.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:5.10: … ate curds after asking for them.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:5.12: “How can nuns eat curds after asking for them?
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:5.13: Who doesn’t like nice food? Who doesn’t want tasty food?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:6.1: The nuns heard the complaints of those people.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:6.2: The nuns of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:6.3: “How can the nuns from the group of six eat curds after asking for them?” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:6.4: “Is it true, monks, that those nuns do this?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:6.7: How can the nuns from the group of six eat curds after asking for them?
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:6.8: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:6.9: And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:7.2: ‘If a nun asks for curds and then eats them, she must acknowledge it:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:7.3: “I have done a blameworthy and unsuitable thing which is to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it.”’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:8.1: In this way the Master laid down this training rule for the nuns.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:9.2: Soon afterwards a number of nuns were sick.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:9.3: The nuns who were looking after them asked,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:9.4: “We hope you’re bearing up; we hope you’re getting better?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:9.5: “Previously we ate curds after asking for them, and then we were comfortable.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:9.6: But now that this has been prohibited by the Master, we don’t ask because we’re afraid of wrongdoing. And because of that we’re not comfortable.” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:9.8: “Monks, I allow a sick nun to eat curds after asking for them.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:9.9: And so, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:10.1: ‘If a nun who is not sick asks for (oil … honey … sugar … fish … meat … milk … ) curds and then eats them, she must acknowledge it:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:10.2: “I have done a blameworthy and unsuitable thing which is to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it.”’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:11.4: … The nun who has been given the full ordination by both complete Orders through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of nun is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:12.2: one who is comfortable without curds.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:13.2: one who is not comfortable without curds.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:14.2: sesame oil, mustard seed oil, honey tree oil, castor oil, oil from tallow.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:15.6: what lives in water is what is meant.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:15.8: the meat of those animals whose meat is allowable.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:15.10: milk from cows, milk from goats, milk from buffaloes, or milk from whatever animal whose meat is allowable.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:15.13: If she is not sick and she asks for her own benefit, then the effort constitutes wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:15.14: When she receives it with the intention of eating it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:15.15: For every mouthful, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:16.1: If she is not sick, and she does not perceive herself as sick, and she eats curds after asking for them, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:16.2: If she is not sick, but she is unsure of it, and she eats curds after asking for them, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:16.3: If she is not sick, but she perceives herself as sick, and she eats curds after asking for them, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:17.1: If she is sick, but she does not perceive herself as sick, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:17.2: If she is sick, but she is unsure if she is, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:17.3: If she is sick, and she perceives herself as sick, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:18.3: if she asked for them when she was sick, but eats them when she is no longer sick;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:18.4: if she eats the leftovers from one who is sick;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:18.6: if it is from those who have given an invitation;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:18.7: if it is for the benefit of someone else;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:18.8: if it is by means of her own property;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:18.10: if she is the first offender.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:19.1: The eighth training rule entailing acknowledgment is finished.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:20.1: “Venerables, the eight rules on offenses entailing acknowledgment have been recited.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:20.2: In regard to this I ask you,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:20.8: You are pure in this and therefore silent. I will remember it thus.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2:20.9: The chapter on offenses entailing acknowledgment in the nuns’ analysis is finished.
